title: Visualisation Guide
text: Mutational signature analysis answers 6 key questions. answer can summarized visualization. observed mutational profile single sample patterns observed mutational profile cohort? samples sample interest similar respect observed mutational profile? mutational signature analysis produce good quality model can draw robust inferences single sample? mutational signature model sample say single sample? patterns mutational signature models cohort? signature X look like?

title: Visualisation Guide
text: 1. Single Sample Visualisation  2A. Cohort stacked bar 2B. Per channel feature distribution cohort context (dotplots)
code: # Load a catalogue tally <- catalogues_load("BRCA", type = "SBS_96")  # Select a single dataframe of interest sample = "TCGA-5L-AAT1-01A-12D-A41F-09" tally_single_sample <- tally[[sample]]  tally_single_sample #> # A tibble: 96 × 4 #>    channel type  fraction count #>    <chr>   <chr>    <dbl> <int> #>  1 A[C>A]A C>A   0.00151      3 #>  2 A[C>A]C C>A   0.00151      3 #>  3 A[C>A]G C>A   0.000503     1 #>  4 A[C>A]T C>A   0            0 #>  5 A[C>G]A C>G   0.00151      3 #>  6 A[C>G]C C>G   0.00151      3 #>  7 A[C>G]G C>G   0            0 #>  8 A[C>G]T C>G   0.00201      4 #>  9 A[C>T]A C>T   0.00402      8 #> 10 A[C>T]C C>T   0.00151      3 #> # ℹ 86 more rows # Visualise it sig_visualise(tally_single_sample, class = "catalogue", title = sample) #> ✔ All channels matched perfectly to set [sbs_96]. Using this set for sort order #> ✔ All types matched perfectly to set [sbs_type]. Using this set for sort order #> ✔ Types matched perfectly to palette [snv_type]

title: Visualisation Guide
text: Often ’ll mutational signature want visualise profile. example lets plot profile signature SBS2 COSMIC database (process work de-novo signatures)  can doublets, indels de novo signatures
code: # Load Signature signatures <- sig_load("COSMIC_v3.3.1_SBS_GRCh38")  # Select just SBS2 sbs2 <- signatures[["SBS2"]]  # Plot sig_visualise(signature = sbs2, title = "SBS2") #> ✔ All channels matched perfectly to set [sbs_96]. Using this set for sort order #> ✔ All types matched perfectly to set [sbs_type]. Using this set for sort order #> ✔ Types matched perfectly to palette [snv_type] # Load Signature signatures <- sig_load("COSMIC_v3.3_DBS_GRCh38")  # Select just SBS2 dbs9 <- signatures[["DBS9"]]  # Plot sig_visualise(signature = dbs9, title = "DBS9") #> ✔ All channels matched perfectly to set [dbs_78]. Using this set for sort order #> ✔ All types matched perfectly to set [doublet_type]. Using this set for sort order #> ✔ Types matched perfectly to palette [dbs_type]

title: Visualisation Guide
text: sig_visualise allows users provide custom colour mappings therefore supports manner custom visualisations.
code: # Create Custom Signature sig_custom <- data.frame(   type = c("INDELS", "INDELS", "SUBSTITUTIONS","SUBSTITUTIONS"),   channel = c("INDELS", "DELETIONS", "SBS", "DOUBLETS"),   fraction = c(0.1, 0.1, 0.7, 0.1)   )  # Custom palette  custom_pal <- c('INDELS' = "darkorange", "SUBSTITUTIONS" = "darkgreen")  # Plot sig_visualise(signature = sig_custom, title = "Custom Signature", palette = custom_pal) #> ! No exact channel set match found, sorting in order of appearance #> ! No exact type set match found, sorting in order of appearance

text: Create interactive visualisations summarise mutational signature analyses

title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: can install development version sigvis like :
code: if (!require("pak", quietly = TRUE))     install.packages("pak")  pak::pak("selkamand/sigverse")

title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
code: library(sigvis) library(sigstash)  # Load Signature signatures <- sig_load("COSMIC_v3.3.1_SBS_GRCh38")  # Select just SBS2 SBS2 <- signatures[["SBS2"]]  # Plot sig_visualise(signature = SBS2, title = "SBS2") #> ✔ All channels matched perfectly to set [sbs_96]. Using this set for sort order #> ✔ All types matched perfectly to set [sbs_type]. Using this set for sort order #> ✔ Types matched perfectly to palette [snv_type]

title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
code: # Load library containing results of TCGA mutational signature analysis library(TCGAcatalogues)   # Load a catalogue tally <- catalogues_load("BRCA", type = "SBS_96")  # Select a single sample of interest sample = "TCGA-5L-AAT1-01A-12D-A41F-09" tally_single_sample <- tally[[sample]]  tally_single_sample #> # A tibble: 96 × 4 #>    channel type  fraction count #>    <chr>   <chr>    <dbl> <int> #>  1 A[C>A]A C>A   0.00151      3 #>  2 A[C>A]C C>A   0.00151      3 #>  3 A[C>A]G C>A   0.000503     1 #>  4 A[C>A]T C>A   0            0 #>  5 A[C>G]A C>G   0.00151      3 #>  6 A[C>G]C C>G   0.00151      3 #>  7 A[C>G]G C>G   0            0 #>  8 A[C>G]T C>G   0.00201      4 #>  9 A[C>T]A C>T   0.00402      8 #> 10 A[C>T]C C>T   0.00151      3 #> # ℹ 86 more rows # Visualise Observed Mutational Profile sig_visualise(tally_single_sample, class = "catalogue", title = sample) #> ✔ All channels matched perfectly to set [sbs_96]. Using this set for sort order #> ✔ All types matched perfectly to set [sbs_type]. Using this set for sort order #> ✔ Types matched perfectly to palette [snv_type]

title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: Visualise catalogue expected signature model, signature ‘SBS2’ explains 60% mutations sample, ‘SBS13’ explains remaining 40%
code: # Load sigstats library for combining signature models library(sigstats)  # Visualise a model (combination of signatures) model = sig_combine(signatures, model = c('SBS2' = 0.6, 'SBS13' = 0.4)) sig_visualise(model, class = 'model', title = "Model", subtitle = "Combination of SBS2 (60%) and SBS13 (40%)") #> ✔ All channels matched perfectly to set [sbs_96]. Using this set for sort order #> ✔ All types matched perfectly to set [sbs_type]. Using this set for sort order #> ✔ Types matched perfectly to palette [snv_type]

what: Visualise a Signature Model Against the Observed Mutation Catalogue
title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: Visualise catalogue expected signature model, signature ‘SBS2’ explains 60% mutations sample, ‘SBS13’ explains remaining 40%, overlay top observed mutational process
code: library(sigstats) # For combining signature models library(sigstash) # For pulling signatures library(TCGAcatalogues) # For pulling example TCGA catalogue data  # Load Signature signatures <- sig_load("COSMIC_v3.3.1_SBS_GRCh38")  # Create a model (combination of signatures) model <- sig_combine(signatures, model = c('SBS2' = 0.6, 'SBS13' = 0.4), format = "signature")  # Load a catalogue (Tally of variant types) tally <- catalogues_load("BRCA", type = "SBS_96")  # Get tally of a single sample sample = "TCGA-5L-AAT1-01A-12D-A41F-09" tally_single_sample <- tally[[sample]]  # Visualise the overlay sig_visualise_compare_reconstructed_to_observed(   catalogue = tally_single_sample,   signature = model ) #> ✔ All channels matched perfectly to set [sbs_96]. Using this set for sort order #> ✔ All types matched perfectly to set [sbs_type]. Using this set for sort order #> ✔ Types matched perfectly to palette [snv_type]

title: Automatically select a color palette based on signature types — auto_palette
text: function takes vector signature 'types' selects appropriate color palette. checks types match predefined palettes returns matching palette default palette pal_set2() exact match found.

title: Automatically select a color palette based on signature types — auto_palette

title: Automatically select a color palette based on signature types — auto_palette
text: types character vector types e.g. sigverse signature 'type' column. default default color palette use exact match found.

title: Visualise Signatures — sig_visualise
text: Visualises Signatures. order channels displayed based order appear signature data.frame

title: Visualise Signatures — sig_visualise
code: sig_visualise(   signature,   class = c("signature", "catalogue", "model"),   title = NULL,   subtitle = NULL,   palette = "auto",   channel_order = "auto",   na.value = "grey",   options = vis_options() )

title: Visualise Signatures — sig_visualise
text: signature sigverse signature object class type input signature. signature (e.g. sigstash database), catalogue (e.g. TCGAcatalogues signature analysis), model (combination signatures designed approximate observed mutational profile) title plot title subtitle plot subtitle palette colours based 'type' column. default 'auto' automatically pick palette values 'type' column matches COSMIC SBS, Doublet Indel mutations. Otherwise named vector names = types values colours. channel_order channels ordered X axis. default 'auto' automatically pick palette channels recognised standard COSMIC SBS/DBS/INDEL signature, sorts alphabetical order. Can also vector channels order appear na.value colour use type = NA options visualisation options. See vis_options() details

title: Visualise Signatures — sig_visualise
text: ggplot object

title: Visualise Signatures — sig_visualise
text: channels match known channel type, channel display order instead based predefined order

title: Visualise Signatures — sig_visualise
code:
library(sigstash) library(sigstats) library(TCGAcatalogues)  # Load Signature signatures <- sig_load('COSMIC_v3.3.1_SBS_GRCh38')  # Visualise a single signature sig_visualise(signatures[["SBS2"]]) #> ✔ All channels matched perfectly to set [sbs_96]. Using this set for sort order #> ✔ All types matched perfectly to set [sbs_type]. Using this set for sort order #> ✔ Types matched perfectly to palette [snv_type]   # Visualise a catalogue brca_catalogues <- catalogues_load('BRCA') sig_visualise(brca_catalogues[["TCGA-3C-AALI-01A-11D-A41F-09"]], class = 'catalogue') #> ✔ All channels matched perfectly to set [sbs_96]. Using this set for sort order #> ✔ All types matched perfectly to set [sbs_type]. Using this set for sort order #> ✔ Types matched perfectly to palette [snv_type]   # Visualise a model (combination of signatures model <- sig_combine(signatures, model = c('SBS2' = 0.5, 'SBS13' = 0.5)) sig_visualise(model, class = 'model') #> ✔ All channels matched perfectly to set [sbs_96]. Using this set for sort order #> ✔ All types matched perfectly to set [sbs_type]. Using this set for sort order #> ✔ Types matched perfectly to palette [snv_type]   # Make Visualisations Interactive gg = sig_visualise(model, class = 'model') #> ✔ All channels matched perfectly to set [sbs_96]. Using this set for sort order #> ✔ All types matched perfectly to set [sbs_type]. what: Compare two signature catalogues by overlaying one over the other — sig_visualise_compare
title: Compare two signature catalogues by overlaying one over the other — sig_visualise_compare
text: Compare two signature catalogues overlaying one

title: Compare two signature catalogues by overlaying one over the other — sig_visualise_compare
code: sig_visualise_compare(   catalogue1,   catalogue2,   compare = c("count", "fraction"),   names = c("Sample 1", "Sample 2"),   channel_order = "auto",   palette = "auto",   na.value = "grey",   subtitle = NULL,   title = NULL,   options = vis_options() )

title: Compare two signature catalogues by overlaying one over the other — sig_visualise_compare
text: catalogue1, catalogue2 sigverse catalogue (tally) representing observed mutational profile (data.frame) compare metric compare (counts fractions) names 2 element character vector describing names used describe catalogue 1 2 retrospectively. channel_order channels ordered X axis. default 'auto' automatically pick palette channels recognised standard COSMIC SBS/DBS/INDEL signature, sorts alphabetical order. Can also vector channels order appear palette colours based 'type' column. default 'auto' automatically pick palette values 'type' column matches COSMIC SBS, Doublet Indel mutations. Otherwise named vector names = types values colours. na.value colour use type = NA subtitle plot subtitle title plot title options visualisation options. See vis_options() details

title: Compare two signature catalogues by overlaying one over the other — sig_visualise_compare
text: ggplot object.

title: Compare two signature catalogues by overlaying one over the other — sig_visualise_compare
code:
library(sigstats) # For combining signature models library(TCGAcatalogues) # For pulling example TCGA catalogue data  # Load a catalogue collection (Tally of variant types) catalogues <- catalogues_load("BRCA", type = "SBS_96")  # Get catalogue of 2 different samples sample1 = "TCGA-OL-A6VQ-01A-12D-A41F-09" sample2 = "TCGA-OL-A97C-01A-32D-A41F-09" catalogue_sample1 <- catalogues[[sample1]] catalogue_sample2 <- catalogues[[sample2]]   # Compare the two catalogues ggcompare <- sig_visualise_compare(   catalogue1 = catalogue_sample1,   catalogue2 = catalogue_sample2 ) #> ✔ All channels matched perfectly to set [sbs_96]. Using this set for sort order #> ✔ All types matched perfectly to set [sbs_type]. Using this set for sort order #> ✔ Types matched perfectly to palette [snv_type]  # Make interactive sig_make_interactive(ggcompare)  {"x":{"html":"<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>

what: Visualise a signature overlayed on observed mutational profile — sig_visualise_compare_reconstructed_to_observed
title: Visualise a signature overlayed on observed mutational profile — sig_visualise_compare_reconstructed_to_observed
text: Visualise signature overlayed observed mutational profile

title: Visualise a signature overlayed on observed mutational profile — sig_visualise_compare_reconstructed_to_observed
code: sig_visualise_compare_reconstructed_to_observed(signature, catalogue, ...)

title: Visualise a signature overlayed on observed mutational profile — sig_visualise_compare_reconstructed_to_observed
text: signature sigverse signature object representing exposure model (data.frame) catalogue sigverse catalogue (tally) representing observed mutational profile (data.frame) ... Arguments passed sig_visualise_compare catalogue1,catalogue2 sigverse catalogue (tally) representing observed mutational profile (data.frame) compare metric compare (counts fractions) names 2 element character vector describing names used describe catalogue 1 2 retrospectively. title plot title subtitle plot subtitle palette colours based 'type' column. default 'auto' automatically pick palette values 'type' column matches COSMIC SBS, Doublet Indel mutations. Otherwise named vector names = types values colours. channel_order channels ordered X axis. default 'auto' automatically pick palette channels recognised standard COSMIC SBS/DBS/INDEL signature, sorts alphabetical order. Can also vector channels order appear na.value colour use type = NA options visualisation options. See vis_options() details

title: Visualise a signature overlayed on observed mutational profile — sig_visualise_compare_reconstructed_to_observed
text: ggplot object.

title: Visualise a signature overlayed on observed mutational profile — sig_visualise_compare_reconstructed_to_observed
code:
library(sigstats) # For combining signature models library(sigstash) # For pulling signatures library(TCGAcatalogues) # For pulling example TCGA catalogue data  # Load Signature signatures <- sig_load("COSMIC_v3.3.1_SBS_GRCh38")  # Create a model (combination of signatures) model <- sig_combine(signatures, model = c('SBS2' = 0.6, 'SBS13' = 0.4)) model_signature <- sig_combine_collapse_to_single_signature(model)  # Load a catalogue (Tally of variant types) tally <- catalogues_load("BRCA", type = "SBS_96")  # Get tally of a single sample sample = "TCGA-5L-AAT1-01A-12D-A41F-09" tally_single_sample <- tally[[sample]]  # Visualise the overlay gg <- sig_visualise_compare_reconstructed_to_observed(   catalogue = tally_single_sample,   signature = model_signature ) #> ✔ All channels matched perfectly to set [sbs_96]. Using this set for sort order #> ✔ All types matched perfectly to set [sbs_type]. Using this set for sort order #> ✔ Types matched perfectly to palette [snv_type]  # Make interactive sig_make_interactive(gg)  {"x":{"html":"<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
